content.caption: Jean Alter Walker in the October 1943 edition of the Purple Parrot, a humor magazine published by students at Northwestern from 1921 to 1950.

Wedding article for Jean Alter and Merton G. Walker, Jr., in the Milwaukee Journal on March 21, 1944. "Given in marriage by her father, the tall slender blond bride was lovely in a period gown of deep ivory satin, a double ruffle of accordion pleated lace forming a pinafore effect on the basque bodice and ending in two satin bows on the back of the frock."

John Ornes and family about 1884. John Ornes, Anna Beer-Ornes, Minnie Kaiser in front, Dora Beer-Alter and Oscar Alter in rear. Probably taken on occasion of Julia Beer's death, which followed Anna and Dora's marriages by a few weeks.

ca. 1910, Manitowoc, Wisconsin.  Oscar A. Alter Drug Store, 208 North Eighth Street, around 1910. Mr. Alter worked as a druggist from 1880 into the early 1900's, then became an employee of the East Wisconsin Trustee Company into the 1930's.
Oscar A. Alter 1861-1945
The History of Manitowoc Lodge No. 65, F. and A.M.
Taken in 1864 on the occasion of their father's death at age 43. Anna, on the left, is 7, and Dora is 4. They look like they've been crying.

This framed miniature portrait of George Beer was kept by his wife, Julia, after his death. With frame it measures about 4.5in by 4in. This type of remembrance disappeared with the growth of photography. Perhaps the lack of a photo of George is why she had one made of her daughters at the death of her husband.
